title: Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD)
scope: ** Diagnostic workup, symptomatic management, and palliative care for suspected or confirmed Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease across all subtypes (sporadic, familial/genetic, iatrogenic, variant). Covers WHO/CDC diagnostic criteria application, biomarker interpretation (RT-QuIC, 14-3-3, tau), neuroimaging (MRI DWI cortical ribboning), EEG (periodic sharp wave complexes), PRNP genotyping, myoclonus management, infection control (prion decontamination), palliative care initiation, family counseling, genetic counseling for familial forms, and autopsy/National Prion Disease Pathology Surveillance Center referral. No disease-modifying treatment exists -- management is entirely supportive and palliative. For comprehensive RPD evaluation including treatable mimics, use the "Rapidly Progressive Dementia" template. For autoimmune encephalitis (key differential), use the "Autoimmune Encephalitis" template.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; infection screen; rule out hematologic causes of encephalopathy
Metabolic encephalopathy screen (hepatic, renal, electrolyte); baseline before medications
Hashimoto encephalopathy (SREAT) is a treatable mimic; hypothyroid encephalopathy
B12 deficiency is a reversible cause of cognitive decline; rule out before accepting prion diagnosis
Vasculitis screen; inflammatory conditions; normal in CJD (helps exclude autoimmune/inflammatory mimics)
Inflammatory marker; elevated suggests non-prion etiology (autoimmune, infection, vasculitis)
Neurosyphilis is a treatable RPD mimic
UTI causing delirium superimposed on CJD

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Hashimoto encephalopathy (SREAT) -- treatable with steroids; can mimic CJD
Lupus cerebritis; systemic autoimmune disease mimicking RPD

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Autoimmune encephalitis panel (serum) -- NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2, GABA-B, GABA-A, AMPA, DPPX, IgLON5
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Treatable autoimmune encephalitis is the most important reversible CJD mimic to identify

Extended Workup (Second-line).item: Paraneoplastic panel (serum) -- comprehensive (ANNA-1/Hu, ANNA-2/Ri, CRMP-5, amphiphysin, PCA-1/Yo, GAD65)
Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Paraneoplastic encephalitis can mimic CJD presentation

Rare/Specialized (Prion-Specific and Gen.rationale: Identifies genetic/familial prion disease (fCJD, GSS, FFI); determines codon 129 polymorphism (methionine/valine) which influences sCJD phenotype and prognosis; important for family counseling
Rare/Specialized (Prion-Specific and Gen.target: No pathogenic mutation; document codon 129 genotype (MM, MV, VV)

Rare/Specialized (Prion-Specific and Gen.rationale: MM homozygosity most common in sCJD-MM1 (classic rapid form); MV and VV associated with different clinical phenotypes and prognosis
Rare/Specialized (Prion-Specific and Gen.target: MM most common in sCJD; VV/MV in some atypical forms

Rare/Specialized (Prion-Specific and Gen.rationale: Markedly elevated in CJD; useful as accessible blood biomarker of neuronal damage; may support diagnosis when CSF unavailable
If PRNP targeted analysis negative but clinical suspicion for genetic prion disease remains high
Rapidly progressive Alzheimer disease is the most common misdiagnosis of CJD; serum AD biomarkers help distinguish
Rare/Specialized (Prion-Specific and Gen.target: Normal p-tau ratio (elevated suggests rpAD, not CJD)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated ICP assessment; typically normal in CJD
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal (10-20 cm H2O); normal in CJD

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Normal or minimal pleocytosis in CJD; elevated WBC suggests autoimmune or infectious etiology
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal in CJD (WBC <5); elevated WBC suggests non-prion diagnosis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Mildly elevated or normal in CJD; markedly elevated suggests infection/autoimmune
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal or mildly elevated in CJD (usually <100 mg/dL)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Low in bacterial/TB/fungal meningitis, carcinomatous meningitis; normal in CJD

GOLD STANDARD for CJD diagnosis. Sensitivity 92%, specificity 99-100%. Detects misfolded prion protein amplification. Send to National Prion Disease Pathology Surveillance Center (Cleveland) or Quest/Mayo
Elevated in rapid neuronal destruction. Sensitivity ~90% for sCJD but NOT specific (also elevated in stroke, encephalitis, seizures, CNS lymphoma). Largely superseded by RT-QuIC
Lumbar Puncture.target: Negative (positive supports CJD in right clinical context but has significant false-positive rate)

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Markedly elevated in CJD (>1150 pg/mL has sensitivity 90%, specificity 86%). Higher levels correlate with more rapid progression. Not specific (also elevated in AD, stroke)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal (<400 pg/mL); CJD often >1150, frequently >10,000 pg/mL

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in CJD (>35 ng/mL); marker of neuronal damage; less specific than tau or RT-QuIC
Markedly elevated in CJD; non-specific marker of neuronal damage; useful for tracking progression

Lumbar Puncture.item: Autoimmune encephalitis panel (CSF) -- NMDAR, LGI1, CASPR2, GABA-B, GABA-A, AMPA, DPPX
Lumbar Puncture.rationale: CSF more sensitive than serum for NMDAR antibodies; rule out treatable autoimmune encephalitis before accepting CJD diagnosis

Lumbar Puncture.item: Alzheimer biomarkers (CSF Abeta42, Abeta40, p-tau 181, t-tau) (CPT 83519)
Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rapidly progressive AD (rpAD) is the most common misdiagnosis of CJD. AD pattern: low Abeta42/Abeta40 ratio + elevated p-tau. In CJD: t-tau markedly elevated but p-tau NOT proportionally elevated (p-tau/t-tau ratio very low)
Lumbar Puncture.target: Context-dependent; p-tau/t-tau ratio helps distinguish CJD from rpAD

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Intrathecal antibody synthesis (MS, autoimmune, neurosarcoidosis); typically absent in CJD
Lumbar Puncture.target: Absent in CJD; present suggests inflammatory/autoimmune etiology

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553) + DWI/FLAIR
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h. DWI is CRITICAL -- cortical ribboning on DWI is highly characteristic of CJD. 3T preferred for sensitivity
Essential/First-line.target: sCJD: cortical ribboning on DWI (high signal in neocortex) + caudate/putamen signal on DWI/FLAIR. vCJD: pulvinar sign (bilateral pulvinar thalamic high signal). fCJD: variable by mutation. Sensitivity of MRI DWI for sCJD >90%
sCJD: periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWCs) at 1-2 Hz -- triphasic morphology; generalized; sensitivity ~65% (highest in sCJD-MM1 subtype). Also rules out non-convulsive status epilepticus

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate if acute presentation, focal deficit, or pre-LP
Essential/First-line.target: Mass lesion; hydrocephalus; hemorrhage; CT is typically normal early in CJD but may show atrophy in later stages

Extended.timing: If altered consciousness, suspected NCSE, or fluctuating exam
Extended.target: Non-convulsive seizures; evolution of PSWCs; helps distinguish CJD periodic pattern from seizures
CJD: cortical and striatal hypometabolism (often asymmetric early); helps distinguish from AD pattern (temporoparietal); may be useful when MRI is equivocal

Extended.timing: If vasculitis suspected as alternative diagnosis

Extended.target: Absent sleep spindles; disrupted sleep architecture; progressive total insomnia

Rare/Specialized.timing: When all non-invasive testing inconclusive and treatable etiology must be excluded; NOT required for CJD diagnosis if RT-QuIC positive and MRI/EEG consistent
Rare/Specialized.target: Spongiform change; PrP immunostaining (definite CJD); also rules out vasculitis, lymphoma, autoimmune
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Coagulopathy; surgical risk; biopsy only changes management if treatable diagnosis possible

Rare/Specialized.timing: If initial MRI read as normal but clinical suspicion for CJD remains high
Rare/Specialized.target: Subtle DWI cortical signal missed on initial read; CJD MRI findings require expertise

Rare/Specialized.timing: Emerging alternative to CSF RT-QuIC; non-invasive; sensitivity 97% in some studies
Rare/Specialized.target: Positive RT-QuIC from olfactory mucosa supports prion diagnosis

dosing.instructions: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg/dose); may repeat x1 in 5 min; max 8 mg total

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Respiratory status; sedation level; airway patency

Acute/Emergent.indication: Seizure prophylaxis and treatment in CJD; preferred first-line ASM due to minimal drug interactions

dosing.instructions: Load 1000-1500 mg IV; maintenance 500-1500 mg PO/IV BID; max 3000 mg/day

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust per CrCl)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Behavioral changes; renal function; seizure frequency

Acute/Emergent.indication: Empiric for Wernicke encephalopathy while RPD workup pending; treat before glucose

dosing.instructions: 500 mg IV TID x 3 days, then 250 mg IV daily x 3-5 days, then 100 mg PO daily

Acute/Emergent.indication: Empiric immunotherapy trial ONLY if autoimmune encephalitis remains in differential; do NOT continue if CJD confirmed (steroids do not help CJD)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Iv Methylprednisolone 1000 mg IV daily x3-5 days

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily x 3-5 days; infuse over 1-2 hours; DISCONTINUE if CJD confirmed

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active untreated infection; CJD confirmed (no benefit); uncontrolled diabetes
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Glucose q6h; BP; GI prophylaxis; clinical response assessment

Symptomatic Treatments -- Myoclonus.indication: Myoclonus -- most effective treatment for CJD-associated myoclonus; reduces startle response and involuntary jerking

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5 mg PO BID; increase by 0.5 mg every 3-5 days as tolerated; target 1-2 mg TID; max 6 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments -- Myoclonus.contraindications: Respiratory depression; severe hepatic impairment; fall risk (elderly); acute narrow-angle glaucoma
Symptomatic Treatments -- Myoclonus.monitoring: Sedation level; respiratory status; fall risk assessment; swallowing function (may worsen dysphagia)

Symptomatic Treatments -- Myoclonus.indication: Myoclonus and seizure control -- add to or substitute for clonazepam if insufficient myoclonus control or excessive sedation from benzodiazepines

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg PO BID; increase by 250 mg every 3-5 days; target level 50-100 mcg/mL; max 2000 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments -- Myoclonus.contraindications: Hepatic disease; pancreatitis; urea cycle disorders; pregnancy (teratogenic)
Symptomatic Treatments -- Myoclonus.monitoring: LFTs; ammonia; CBC (thrombocytopenia); drug level q1-2 weeks until stable; pancreatitis symptoms

Symptomatic Treatments -- Myoclonus.indication: Myoclonus -- alternative or adjunct when benzodiazepine sedation is limiting; also provides seizure coverage

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg PO BID; increase by 500 mg/day every 1-2 weeks; max 3000 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments -- Myoclonus.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust per CrCl)
Symptomatic Treatments -- Myoclonus.monitoring: Behavioral changes (irritability, aggression); renal function; seizure/myoclonus diary

Symptomatic Treatments -- Myoclonus.indication: Cortical myoclonus -- may be effective for CJD myoclonus; not FDA-approved in US but available internationally

dosing.instructions: Start 2400 mg PO TID; may increase to 4800 mg TID; max 24 g/day

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.indication: Agitation, psychosis, behavioral disturbance in CJD -- preferred atypical antipsychotic due to lower EPS risk

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg PO qHS; increase by 25 mg/day every 2-3 days; max 200-400 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.contraindications: QTc prolongation; Lewy body dementia (must distinguish from CJD -- DLB has worse antipsychotic sensitivity)
Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.monitoring: QTc; metabolic panel; sedation; fall risk; EPS monitoring

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.indication: Acute severe agitation or psychosis not responsive to reorientation and non-pharmacologic measures

dosing.instructions: 0.5-2 mg IV/IM q4-6h PRN agitation; use lowest effective dose; max 10 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.contraindications: QTc >500 ms; Parkinson disease; neuroleptic malignant syndrome history
Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.monitoring: ECG (QTc before and after); EPS; NMS surveillance (temperature, rigidity, CPK)

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.indication: Sleep disruption and insomnia -- common in CJD; preferred over benzodiazepine hypnotics to avoid excessive sedation

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg PO qHS; increase by 25 mg every 3-5 days; max 150 mg qHS

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs; QTc prolongation; priapism risk

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.indication: Sleep-wake cycle disruption -- may be tried first given excellent safety profile

dosing.instructions: 3-10 mg PO qHS; start at 3 mg

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.indication: Pain, suffering, and distress in advanced CJD -- palliative intent; myoclonus can be painful

dosing.instructions: Start 1-2 mg IV q2-4h PRN; titrate to comfort; convert to scheduled dosing if frequent PRN use

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.contraindications: Respiratory depression (acceptable in comfort-focused care); severe hepatic impairment
Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.monitoring: Respiratory rate; comfort level; sedation; bowel function (constipation prophylaxis)

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.indication: Pain and distress management in home hospice setting

dosing.instructions: Immediate release: 5-10 mg PO q4h PRN; convert to sustained-release when dose established; sublingual concentrated solution for dysphagia

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.contraindications: Respiratory depression (acceptable in comfort-focused care); severe hepatic impairment
Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.monitoring: Respiratory rate; comfort level; sedation; bowel function; stool softener/laxative prophylaxis

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.indication: Excessive drooling/sialorrhea -- common in advanced CJD with bulbar dysfunction

dosing.instructions: Start 1 mg PO TID; increase to 2 mg TID as needed

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.contraindications: Narrow-angle glaucoma; urinary retention; GI obstruction
Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.monitoring: Anticholinergic effects; urinary retention; constipation; dry mouth

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.indication: Alternative for sialorrhea management when oral medications difficult due to dysphagia

dosing.instructions: Apply 1 transdermal patch behind ear every 72 hours; rotate ears

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.monitoring: Confusion (may worsen); dry mouth; urinary retention

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.indication: Nausea and vomiting -- may occur with brainstem involvement or medication side effects

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV q8h PRN; or 4-8 mg PO q8h PRN

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.indication: Constipation prevention -- universal need with immobility and opioid use

dosing.instructions: Docusate 100 mg PO BID + senna 8.6 mg PO BID; titrate senna to effect
17 g PO daily in 8 oz water; may increase to BID

Symptomatic Treatments -- Behavioral and.monitoring: Bowel frequency; electrolytes if prolonged use

Palliative Care Interventions.indication: All confirmed CJD patients -- initiate goals of care discussion at diagnosis; median survival 5-6 months for sCJD

dosing.instructions: Goals of care discussion; advance directive completion; POLST/MOLST completion; hospice referral when appropriate

Palliative Care Interventions.monitoring: Goals of care revisited at each visit; functional status; caregiver burden

Palliative Care Interventions.indication: Prognosis <6 months (applies to most sCJD at diagnosis); patient/family ready for comfort-focused approach

dosing.instructions: Per hospice agency; home hospice preferred if safe; inpatient hospice if symptoms uncontrolled or caregiver unable

Palliative Care Interventions.contraindications: Patient/family not ready; still pursuing curative workup for non-CJD diagnosis

Palliative Care Interventions.indication: Medication reconciliation -- stop statins, antihypertensives, diabetes medications, preventive therapies that no longer serve goals of care

dosing.instructions: Gradual taper or discontinuation per clinical judgment

Palliative Care Interventions.contraindications: Do not abruptly stop benzodiazepines, opioids, or anticonvulsants (taper if discontinuing)
Palliative Care Interventions.monitoring: Comfort; symptom control after medication changes

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (prion/neurodegenerative specialist if available) for diagnostic confirmation, prognostication, and ongoing management
Palliative care for goals of care discussion, symptom management, advance care planning, and hospice referral coordination

National Prion Disease Pathology Surveillance Center (NPDPSC, Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, OH; phone 1-216-368-0587) for diagnostic guidance, RT-QuIC testing, and potential autopsy coordination
Genetic counseling for familial CJD evaluation, PRNP testing implications, and family member risk assessment
Psychiatry for behavioral symptom management, capacity evaluation, and caregiver psychiatric support
Social work for advance directive facilitation, caregiver support, insurance/disability assistance, and community resources
Ethics consultation for end-of-life decision-making, especially if family conflict about goals of care or capacity questions
Speech-language pathology for dysphagia evaluation and aspiration risk assessment to guide feeding recommendations
Physical therapy for safety assessment, mobility aids, and fall prevention as motor function declines
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, caregiver training for safe transfers, and home safety evaluation
Chaplain/spiritual care for patient and family spiritual support during terminal diagnosis
Infection control/hospital epidemiology for prion decontamination protocols and staff education
CJD Foundation (www.cjdfoundation.org) referral for patient and family support, educational resources, and peer connections

Patient and Family Instructions.item: CJD is NOT contagious through casual contact, sharing meals, kissing, or caring for the patient -- standard household precautions are sufficient; no isolation needed at home
CJD has no cure or disease-modifying treatment; management focuses entirely on comfort, symptom control, and quality of life
Return to ED immediately if new seizures, choking/aspiration, inability to swallow, high fever, or sudden worsening of symptoms
Complete advance directives and healthcare power of attorney EARLY while patient can still participate in decision-making (capacity declines rapidly in CJD)
Do NOT drive at any point after CJD diagnosis due to progressive cognitive and motor impairment
Ensure 24/7 supervision due to fall risk, wandering, impaired judgment, and progressive functional decline
Notify all surgical, dental, and medical providers of CJD diagnosis -- special instrument sterilization or single-use instruments required for any invasive procedure
Blood, organ, and tissue donation is NOT permitted with CJD diagnosis
Contact the CJD Foundation (1-800-659-1991 or www.cjdfoundation.org) for family support resources, educational materials, and peer support groups
Autopsy is strongly encouraged for definitive diagnosis, disease surveillance, and scientific research -- discuss with NPDPSC early; autopsy is provided at no cost through the Surveillance Center
Familial CJD: first-degree relatives should be offered genetic counseling and PRNP testing if mutation identified in proband

Infection Control, Safety & Lifestyle.item: Standard precautions only for routine patient care (gloves, gown as needed); CJD is NOT transmitted by respiratory droplets, blood, urine, or feces in normal care

Prion decontamination for surgical instruments: instruments contacting high-infectivity tissues (brain, spinal cord, eye) must be destroyed or undergo WHO-recommended decontamination (1N NaOH for 1 hour followed by autoclaving at 134 degrees C for 1 hour in a gravity displacement autoclave)
Standard sterilization is INSUFFICIENT for prion decontamination -- conventional autoclaving, ethylene oxide, formaldehyde, alcohol, and UV do not reliably inactivate prions
Single-use disposable instruments recommended for any invasive procedure on confirmed or suspected CJD patients
Avoid LP needle reuse; dispose of all LP supplies as biohazard (standard practice)
CSF handling: standard laboratory precautions are adequate; prion concentration in CSF is very low; gloves and eye protection for splash risk
Endoscopy in CJD patients: use disposable accessories where possible; standard endoscope reprocessing may be insufficient for prion decontamination -- consult infection control
Fall prevention measures: bed alarm, non-slip surfaces, grab bars, low bed, hip protectors for patients with gait instability and myoclonus
Aspiration precautions: head of bed elevated 30 degrees; thickened liquids if dysphagia present; SLP evaluation for safe diet recommendations
Skin integrity: frequent repositioning every 2 hours; pressure-relieving mattress; skin assessment daily for immobile patients

Caregiver self-care: encourage caregivers to maintain their own medical appointments, sleep hygiene, nutrition, and social connections; connect with respite care services and CJD Foundation peer support groups

Home safety modifications: remove tripping hazards (rugs, cords); install grab bars in bathroom; ensure adequate lighting; consider hospital bed for advanced disease; secure medications and hazardous items
Maintain structured daily routine with consistent sleep-wake schedule, regular mealtimes, and familiar environment to reduce confusion and agitation

differential.features: Most common misdiagnosis of CJD; positive AD biomarkers (low Abeta42, elevated p-tau); no myoclonus typically early on; MRI shows atrophy without DWI cortical ribboning; slower course (years not months)
differential.tests: CSF AD biomarkers (Abeta42/Abeta40 ratio low, p-tau elevated, p-tau/t-tau ratio higher than CJD); RT-QuIC negative; MRI without cortical ribboning

differential.features: Subacute onset; psychiatric symptoms prominent (NMDAR); faciobrachial dystonic seizures (LGI1); steroid-responsive; CSF pleocytosis common
differential.tests: Autoimmune encephalitis antibody panel (CSF and serum); MRI mesial temporal signal (LGI1); response to immunotherapy; RT-QuIC negative

differential.features: Elevated anti-TPO; steroid-responsive; cognitive fluctuation; seizures; may mimic CJD closely; diagnosis of exclusion
differential.tests: Anti-TPO and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies; empiric steroid trial (dramatic improvement supports diagnosis); RT-QuIC negative

differential.features: B symptoms; enhancing mass (primary CNS lymphoma); multifocal white matter changes + elevated LDH (intravascular lymphoma); no myoclonus
differential.tests: MRI with contrast (enhancement); CSF cytology + flow cytometry; LDH; peripheral blood smear; brain biopsy

differential.features: RPR/VDRL positive; Argyll Robertson pupils; psychiatric symptoms; may have CSF pleocytosis
differential.tests: RPR/VDRL (serum); CSF VDRL; FTA-ABS; LP with CSF analysis

differential.features: Acute onset; fever; CSF pleocytosis; MRI temporal lobe signal (HSV); seizures
differential.tests: HSV PCR (CSF); viral panels; MRI temporal enhancement; CSF pleocytosis present

differential.features: Known malignancy history; cranial neuropathies; communicating hydrocephalus
differential.tests: CSF cytology (repeat x3); MRI with contrast (leptomeningeal enhancement); known primary malignancy

differential.features: Headache; multifocal deficits; strokes; CSF pleocytosis; ESR/CRP elevated
differential.tests: MRA (beading); DSA; ESR/CRP; brain/meningeal biopsy; ANCA

differential.features: Visual hallucinations; parkinsonism; REM sleep behavior disorder; fluctuating cognition; slower progression
differential.tests: DaT scan (reduced dopamine transporter); clinical criteria; response to cholinesterase inhibitors; no DWI cortical ribboning

differential.features: Medication toxicity; substance abuse; hepatic/uremic/electrolyte encephalopathy; reversible
differential.tests: Drug levels; LFTs; ammonia; BUN/Cr; UDS; correction of metabolic derangement improves cognition

differential.features: Altered consciousness; may have subtle motor signs; EEG shows electrographic seizures not periodic discharges
differential.tests: Continuous EEG (seizure activity vs PSWCs); response to benzodiazepine trial; MRI without CJD pattern

differential.features: Triad: gait (predominant) + urinary incontinence + dementia; ventricular enlargement disproportionate to atrophy
differential.tests: Large-volume LP with pre/post gait assessment; MRI (Evans index >0.3, disproportionate ventriculomegaly)

differential.features: Genetic prion disease (PRNP D178N-129M); progressive insomnia; autonomic dysfunction; late motor/cognitive decline; family history
differential.tests: PRNP gene testing; polysomnography (absent sleep spindles); FDG-PET (thalamic hypometabolism)

differential.features: Genetic prion disease; cerebellar ataxia predominant; slower course (2-10 years); family history
differential.tests: PRNP gene testing (P102L most common); cerebellar atrophy on MRI; slower than sCJD

evidence.recommendation: RT-QuIC for CJD diagnosis (sensitivity 92%, specificity 99-100%) -- gold standard CSF prion biomarker
evidence.source: [McGuire et al. (Ann Neurol 2012)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22926858/); [Atarashi et al. (Nat Med 2011)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21278748/)

evidence.recommendation: MRI DWI cortical ribboning for CJD diagnosis (sensitivity >90%)

evidence.source: [Muayqil et al. (BMC Neurol 2012)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22993290/); WHO diagnostic criteria

evidence.recommendation: CSF total tau >1150 pg/mL for CJD diagnosis (sensitivity 90%, specificity 86%)
CDC diagnostic criteria for probable sporadic CJD (updated 2018)
WHO surveillance criteria for CJD classification (definite, probable, possible)
evidence.source: [WHO Manual for Surveillance of Human Transmissible Spongiform Encephalopathies (2003)](https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/WHO-CDS-CSR-EPH-2002-6)

evidence.recommendation: EEG periodic sharp wave complexes in CJD -- sensitivity ~65% (highest in MM1 subtype)
PRNP codon 129 polymorphism influences CJD phenotype and susceptibility
Molecular classification of sCJD subtypes (MM1, VV2, MV2K, etc.)
No disease-modifying treatment exists for CJD; multiple clinical trials have failed
evidence.source: [Stewart et al. (Neurology 2008)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19711662/) -- quinacrine trial; [Geschwind et al. (Ann Neurol 2013)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24298908/) -- quinacrine RCT

evidence.recommendation: Rapidly progressive AD is the most common misdiagnosis of CJD
evidence.source: [Paterson et al. (Brain 2012)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22744790/); NPDPSC autopsy series data

evidence.recommendation: Prion decontamination requires NaOH + extended autoclaving; standard sterilization insufficient
Pulvinar sign (bilateral pulvinar high signal on MRI) characteristic of variant CJD
National Prion Disease Pathology Surveillance Center (NPDPSC) for diagnostic referral and autopsy
Serum neurofilament light chain (NfL) markedly elevated in CJD; emerging blood biomarker
CSF p-tau/t-tau ratio distinguishes CJD from Alzheimer disease
Palliative care approach recommended for all confirmed CJD patients at diagnosis
Nasal brushing RT-QuIC as emerging non-invasive prion diagnostic (sensitivity ~97%)

monitoring.item: Cognitive assessment (MMSE, MoCA, or bedside exam)
monitoring.frequency: Baseline; weekly inpatient; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: Document rate of decline; adjust prognosis; guide goals of care

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (myoclonus, focal signs, gait, cranial nerves, akinetic mutism)
monitoring.action: Adjust symptomatic medications (clonazepam for myoclonus); update prognosis

monitoring.frequency: Weekly inpatient; each outpatient visit; urgent if coughing with meals
monitoring.action: Modified diet texture; NG tube or PEG tube discussion if progressive; aspiration precautions
Increase caregiver support; modify care plan; facility placement if home care insufficient

monitoring.frequency: Continuous clinical observation; EEG if suspected subclinical seizures
monitoring.action: Adjust ASM dosing; add second agent; cEEG if unclear
Titrate clonazepam; add valproic acid; adjust doses

monitoring.frequency: Each shift inpatient; each visit outpatient
monitoring.action: Chest X-ray if fever/tachypnea; antibiotics for aspiration PNA (if consistent with goals of care); supplemental O2
Nutritional supplementation; feeding tube discussion; palliative nutrition approach
Pressure-relieving surfaces; repositioning schedule; wound care if needed
Respite care; support groups; social work referral; facility placement if caregiver unable to continue
Increase supervision; bed alarm; sitters; facility placement

monitoring.frequency: Weekly until stable; then q1-3 months

disposition.criteria: Stable symptoms with adequate 24/7 caregiver; myoclonus and seizures controlled; safe swallowing or appropriate feeding plan; hospice/palliative care arranged; outpatient neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks; advance directives completed

New diagnosis requiring urgent workup (LP, MRI, EEG); uncontrolled seizures or myoclonus; acute decline requiring medication adjustment; aspiration pneumonia (if consistent with goals of care); caregiver inability to manage at home; goals of care discussion needed
Status epilepticus; respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation (if consistent with goals of care); severe autonomic instability; refractory agitation requiring continuous sedation
Prion disease expertise for diagnostic confirmation; clinical trial enrollment; complex diagnostic workup (brain biopsy consideration); genetic counseling for familial forms
Progressive functional decline exceeding home caregiver capacity; safety concerns (falls, wandering, aspiration) not manageable at home
Confirmed CJD diagnosis with prognosis <6 months (applies to most sCJD at diagnosis); patient/family goals aligned with comfort-focused care; symptom management as primary goal
